page.title: 18Local History
page.content: There is evidence that this area has been inhabited and prosperous for thousands of years. The Long Barrow marked on survey maps was a pre-Roman burial mound. The Saxon churches and the medieval Manor House indicate village life continuing through to the Middle Ages. The circular dovecot near the Manor House is said to be one of the oldest in the British Isles. The wool trade flourished in the Cotswolds and the market town of Cirencester was convenient for the local farmers. The advent and increase of mechanised transport has brought a new type of prosperity to the area bringing a changing community of commuters who work in cities as far away as London. Sadly this has led to the loss of some village amenities.
